Neural Architecture

Our model mimics the structure of the building thermal dynamics model and leverages penalty methods to model inequality constraints. We use constrained matrix parameterization based on the Perron-Frobenius theorem to bound the eigenvalues of the learned network weights. We interpret the stable eigenvalues as dissipativeness of the learned building thermal model. We demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach on a dataset obtained from an office building with 20 thermal zones.

Introduction

Energy-efficient buildings are a top priority to sustainably address global energy demands and reduce CO2 emissions. Advanced control strategies for buildings have been identified as a potential solution with projected energy-saving potential up to 28%. The current state-of-the-art approaches in the domain are based on constrained optimal control methods and heavily depend on mathematical models of the building dynamics. The building thermal behavior is characterized by high-dimensional, nonlinear, and often discontinuous dynamics, which requires expertise and development time. Moreover, high computational demands and non-differentiability can make physics-based models unsuitable for efficient gradient-based optimization.

Data-driven system identification typically represents a more cost-efficient alternative. However, purely black-box models require a large amount of data and may not generalize well outside the training distribution. On the other hand, identifying accurate and reliable physics-based models with constraints from data remains a challenging task and involves solving difficult non-convex optimization problems. As a consequence, many current control-oriented modeling approaches for buildings still rely on crude approximations assuming low-order linear dynamics, which may hamper overall control performance.

In this paper, we show how to train physics-constrained recurrent neural dynamics models to efficiently learn building thermal dynamics in an end-to-end fashion, with physically coherent generalization, from small datasets. Our model is inspired by a family of neural state-space models (SSM), representing structurally modified vanilla RNNs tailored for the modeling of dynamical systems for control.

Methods

Building Thermal Dynamics

When developing predictive models for control purposes, one must balance model complexity, robustness, and accuracy. The typical building envelope dynamics is represented by a model with a graph structure. Mathematically, the thermal building model is given by the following differential equation with nonlinear input and disturbance dynamics:

xt+1 = Axt + But + fd(dt)
yt = Cxt
ut = _mt * cp * Tt

where xt and yt represent the values of the states (envelope temperatures) and measurements (zone temperatures) at time t, respectively. Disturbances dt represent the influence of weather and occupancy behavior. Heat flows delivered to the building uk are the product of mass flows _mt, the difference of the supply and return temperatures Tt, and the specific heat capacity constant cp.

When the model is built with perfect knowledge from first principles, it is physically interpretable. However, every building represents a unique system with different operational conditions. Therefore, obtaining the parameters of the differential equations from first principles is a time-consuming, impractical task.
